<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fpublic%20and%20social%20sector%2Four%20insights%2Fhow%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility%2Fhow-hbcus-accelerate-black-economic-mobility-vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="how-hbcus-accelerate-black-economic-mobility-vf" data-layer-report-name="how-hbcus-accelerate-black-economic-mobility-vf>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (15 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>The first higher-education institution</strong> for Black Americans in the United States was founded in 1837.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf674d2c-9cc2-4c75-afe0-f17cf9dc9f14"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf674d2c-9cc2-4c75-afe0-f17cf9dc9f14" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cheyney University was founded in 1837 as the African Institute; the institution’s name went through several iterations and was finally renamed 		Cheyney University of Pennsylvania in 1983. </span></span></span></a></span> Since then, historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) have established themselves as anchor institutions in their communities and critical platforms for the education and advancement of students of color. HBCUs confer 17 percent of all bachelor’s degrees awarded to Black students in the United States,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7c8ebf49-b62a-4195-a413-b4783a02f9cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7c8ebf49-b62a-4195-a413-b4783a02f9cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>HBCUs punching above their weight</em>, UNCF, June 26, 2019, uncf.org.</span></span></span></a></span> have boosted their students into higher-income quintiles and into prominent political positions,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a2a55eb2-33cc-46ae-9c8f-ec3e4a555b06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a2a55eb2-33cc-46ae-9c8f-ec3e4a555b06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Crystal R. Sanders, “Historically Black colleges and universities are remaking American politics,” <em>Washington Post</em>, November 10, 2020, 		washingtonpost.com.</span></span></span></a></span> and continue to be key sources of talent. And they are doing all of this with endowments that are seven times smaller, on average, than those of non-HBCUs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3e325f94-9d05-4642-bbaa-35171e5005e8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3e325f94-9d05-4642-bbaa-35171e5005e8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, National Center for Education Statistics, July 2021, nces.ed.gov. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This article is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/frankki-bevins">Frankki Bevins</a>, Kathryn Fox, Duwain Pinder, <a href="/our-people/jimmy-sarakatsannis">Jimmy Sarakatsannis</a>, and <a href="/our-people/shelley-stewart">Shelley Stewart III</a>, representing views from the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility.</div></div></div></div></div></div> <!-- -->
<p>HBCUs have an opportunity to accelerate Black economic mobility even more. Recent events have prompted philanthropists and large corporations
to donate to and partner with HBCUs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f444b9c5-94e3-4be1-9474-8140787a1793"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f444b9c5-94e3-4be1-9474-8140787a1793" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Curtis Bunn, “From Covid aid to record donations: Influx of funding helps keep HBCUs’ doors open,” NBC News, February 19, 2021, nbcnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span> If such attention and funding could be sustained—and increased—HBCUs could help to unlock not only more advancement for Black Americans but also strong economic performance for the United States. In fact, our data show that a strong HBCU network could increase Black worker incomes by around $10 billion in addition to strengthening the economy with $1.2 billion in incremental business profit, $300 million in decreased student-loan debt, and $1 billion in additional consumer expenditures.</p>
<p>As the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility (BEM) and the McKinsey Global Institute (MGI) <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">found in their recent report</a>, significant economic and human value can be gained when Black Americans, playing critical economic roles as workers, entrepreneurs and business owners, consumers, savers and investors, and residents, are fully engaged in the economy. HBCUs are uniquely positioned to foster such engagement. </p>
<p>In this article, we outline how HBCUs have substantively improved the economic and educational positions of Black Americans and others in the United States. We also consider the impact these institutions could have for individuals who play the critical roles in the economy cited earlier—and the prosperity they could unleash for many communities. </p>
<h2>The impact of HBCUs</h2>
<p>HBCUs were established in the United States in the early 19th century out of necessity: most US colleges at the time prohibited Black students
from attending. And even up to a century after the end of slavery, Black students were still not welcome at many public and private higher-education institutions. Today, more than 100 institutions in the United States identify as HBCUs, with total average annual attendance of around 300,000 students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1b586438-7c96-482c-b063-fc876b06f211"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1b586438-7c96-482c-b063-fc876b06f211" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Historically Black colleges and universities,” National Center for Education Statistics, July 2021, nces.ed.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> And they consistently deliver strong outcomes, especially on economic mobility (Exhibit 1). </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility/svgz-hbcu-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Historically Black colleges and universities consistently deliver strong outcomes, especially on economic mobility." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility/svgz-hbcu-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Supporting students</h3>
<p>HBCUs represent just 3 percent of all higher-education institutions in the United States, but 10 percent of all Black students matriculating through US colleges are enrolled at HBCUs. What’s more, 17 percent of all bachelor’s degrees and 24 percent of all STEM-related bachelor’s degrees earned by Black students in the United States were conveyed by HBCUs, according to a 2019 report.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1bf1f3e5-5b37-486c-9924-9f5afcf59141"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1bf1f3e5-5b37-486c-9924-9f5afcf59141" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“HBCUs punching above their weight: State performance,” UNCF, August 27, 2019, uncf.org.</span></span></span></a></span> HBCUs also supply more Black applicants to medical schools than non-HBCU institutions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="82ccbf7f-8159-4f9c-8ed5-047ed5f75d6c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="82ccbf7f-8159-4f9c-8ed5-047ed5f75d6c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Marybeth Gasman et al., “HBCUs and the production of doctors,” <em>AIMS Public Health</em>, 2017, Volume 4, Number 6,  pp. 579–89, aimspress.com.</span></span></span></a></span> And HBCUs have graduated 40 percent of all Black engineers; 40 percent of all Black US Congress members; 50 percent of all Black lawyers; and 80 percent of all Black judges.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="30b5a196-bf55-4e2c-989d-795ff8b02d43"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="30b5a196-bf55-4e2c-989d-795ff8b02d43" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">About HBCUs, Thurgood Marshall College Fund, tmcf.org. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>These institutions enroll more than twice as many Pell Grant-eligible (low-income) students as non-HBCU institutions and help create economic mobility for those populations. Graduates of HBCUs are 51 percent more likely to move into a higher-income quintile than graduates of non-HBCUs. The mean mobility rate across all US colleges is 1.6 percent, but the mean mobility rate for HBCUs is 3.0 percent<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="de1287ac-6e09-4f6a-881a-1d3a5fc85926"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="de1287ac-6e09-4f6a-881a-1d3a5fc85926" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Data Library, Opportunity Insights, July 2021, opportunityinsights.org; Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, July 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility/svgz-hbcu-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The mean mobility rate for HBCUs is 3.0 percent, nearly double that of all colleges in the United States." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility/svgz-hbcu-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In addition to academic and economic outcomes, HBCUs positively contribute to the physical health of their attendees. A recently published study found that Black students who attended an HBCU were less likely to develop risk factors for chronic disease later in life than those who attended predominantly White institutions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d9e6818-1759-4864-85ce-3bfdfb1ff892"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d9e6818-1759-4864-85ce-3bfdfb1ff892" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kierra S. Barnett, Cynthia G. Colen, and Nicolo P. Pinchak, “Racial disparities in health among college-educated African Americans: Can 		  attendance at historically Black colleges or universities reduce the risk of metabolic syndrome in midlife?” <em>American Journal of Epidemiology</em>, 		  April 2021, Volume 190, Issue 4, pp. 553–61, academicoup.com. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Additionally, Black HBCU graduates are more than twice as likely as Black graduates of non-HBCUs to report having experienced three major support measures while at school—for example, a professor who cared about them as a person; a professor who made them excited about learning; or a mentor who encouraged them to pursue their goals and dreams.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2a94f207-c6e1-4787-b831-37b5fd1a1ee9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2a94f207-c6e1-4787-b831-37b5fd1a1ee9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Gallup-USA Funds minority college graduates report</em>, joint report from Gallup and United Student Aid Funds, 2015, gallup.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The positive effects of such support extend into these graduates’ lives long after graduation: Black HBCU graduates report higher levels of well-being across many areas, including measures of purpose, social well-being, financial well-being, and engagement at work.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a2ed632a-019b-47ac-b32b-aab3955d3d87"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a2ed632a-019b-47ac-b32b-aab3955d3d87" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Gallup-USA Funds minority college graduates report</em>, joint report from Gallup and United Student Aid Funds, 2015, gallup.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<h3>Serving the community</h3>
<p>Eighty-one percent of HBCUs are located in US counties where the median wage is below the national average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3de3e16b-873c-48fc-8779-fe79263e27e9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3de3e16b-873c-48fc-8779-fe79263e27e9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">US Census Bureau, July 2021, data.census.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, 65 percent of HBCUs, compared with 47 percent of non-HBCUs, are in geographic areas where past and projected net job growth is slower than average (Exhibit 3). </p>
<!-- -->
<p>Without HBCUs, the economic prospects of these communities could be even worse. According to one report, the nation’s HBCUs create 134,090 jobs for their local and regional economies, and every dollar spent by an HBCU and its students generates $1.44 in spending for local economies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2a451874-fd2d-4660-9dad-347752a1cb02"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2a451874-fd2d-4660-9dad-347752a1cb02" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“HBCUs make America strong,” UNCF, November 14, 2017, uncf.org.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>What’s more, there is an “inherent trust” and “cultural sensitivity” built up over time among HBCUs and the neighborhoods and communities in which they operate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c300ede5-9b57-4a37-a8fe-6b60b97cb7b5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c300ede5-9b57-4a37-a8fe-6b60b97cb7b5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kelly Field, “Why HBCUs are taking an active role in COVID-19 testing and vaccine efforts,” Higher Ed Dive, November 2, 2020, highereddive.com.</span></span></span></a></span> HBCUs can leverage this trust to offer much-needed services and programs to their communities, including skills training, food pantries, and medical clinics—and, just recently, COVID-19-related services. For instance, during the pandemic, Alabama State University partnered with state and local officials to provide free COVID-19 testing for public-housing residents in its hometown of Montgomery.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="250cc41f-d983-407b-ba00-2a180844e84a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="250cc41f-d983-407b-ba00-2a180844e84a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kelly Field, “Why HBCUs are taking an active role in COVID-19 testing and vaccine efforts,” Higher Ed Dive, November 2, 2020, highereddive.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>HBCUs: Engines for economic growth</h2>
<p><a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">A recent report</a> released by MGI and BEM examines the status of Black Americans, how they are served by public programs, and why addressing any identified gaps could transform lives. We believe HBCUs are uniquely positioned to help fill these gaps—and lift up Black Americans—given their assets, experience, and cultural and historical significance. What follows is an overview of the role HBCUs can play to support Black workers, entrepreneurs and business owners, consumers, savers and investors, and residents. We discuss the actions these institutions can take to accelerate their impact among the students they serve and within the communities in which they operate. </p>
<h3>1. Expanding opportunities for Black workers</h3>
<p><a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">According to our research</a>, Black Americans in the workforce earn a median annual wage that is approximately 30 percent, or $10,000, lower than that of White workers. More than 60 percent of that gap is driven by less than 4 percent of all occupational categories, with Black workers overrepresented in low-wage jobs and underrepresented in higher-wage jobs. Although Black Americans represent around 13 percent of the total US population, they account
for only 5 percent of physicians and 4.5 percent of software developers, for example—but more than 35 percent of all US nursing assistants.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>How we calculated the increased income opportunity for Black American workers</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>In 2019, HBCUs</strong> produced around 33,000 bachelor’s degrees, with an estimated 80 percent of those degrees conferred on Black Americans.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a48a5edf-8dce-49b9-8dd8-864fd085b2cc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a48a5edf-8dce-49b9-8dd8-864fd085b2cc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, National Center for Education Statistics, July 2021, nces.ed.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> To calculate the impact of improved student outcomes at HBCUs on worker incomes, we reviewed five scenarios focused on three levers: enrollment growth, improved graduation rates, and enhanced postgraduate earnings.</p>
<p>In each scenario, we do not estimate any incremental growth in wages, therefore the results are a low-end estimate of the scenario’s impact.</p>
<h4>Scenario 1: Enrollment growth</h4>
<p>In this scenario, we assume that the number of HBCU degrees awarded to Black Americans each year would increase between 1 and 3 percent over the next ten years. To calculate the income impact, we estimated the net present value (NPV) of a college education (using a 2 percent discount rate, an average net price of an HBCU at $15,000 for five years, and the average wage of a Black college graduate at $62,000 relative to the average wage of a Black high-school graduate at $36,000<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="42adfe0c-9e83-4f35-859d-f76cbdcc884e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="42adfe0c-9e83-4f35-859d-f76cbdcc884e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“US Census Bureau releases 2014-2018 ACS 5-year estimates,” US Census Bureau, December 19, 2019, census.gov.</span></span></span></a></span>).</p>
<h4>Scenario 2: Improved graduation rates</h4>
<p>In this scenario, we assume that the number of degrees per student for each HBCU would improve from the current rate of 16 percent (one degree for every six students) to between 19 and 21 percent (the median degrees per student for all non-HBCU institutions, equivalent to one degree for around every five students). This would increase the number of degrees produced at HBCUs. To calculate the income impact, we estimated the NPV of
a college education (using a 2 percent discount rate, an average net price of an HBCU at $15,000 for five years, and the average wage of a Black college graduate at $62,000 relative to the average wage of a Black student with some college education at around $40,000).</p>
<h4>Scenario 3: Enhanced postgraduate earnings</h4>
<p>In this scenario, we assume that the average earnings for a Black college graduate of around $61,000 would increase by
$5,000 to $7,000, reflecting the potential increased demand for HBCU graduates. To calculate the income impact, we estimated the NPV of a college education (using a 2 percent discount rate, an average net price of an HBCU at $15,000 for five years, and the average wage of a Black college graduate at around $67,000 to $69,000 relative to the average wage of a Black high-school graduate at around $36,000).</p>
<h4>Scenario 4: Enrollment and graduation-rate improvements</h4>
<p>This scenario includes the assumptions for Scenario 1 and Scenario 2.</p>
<h4>Scenario 5: Enrollment, graduation-rate and earnings improvements</h4>
<p>This scenario includes the assumptions for Scenario 4, in addition to the earnings improvements in Scenario 3.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>HBCUs can accelerate progress for Black workers primarily by enrolling more students and by graduating a higher share of them. Our research suggests that higher enrollment and retention and graduation rates could translate to an increase in Black worker incomes of $10 billion per year (see sidebar “How we calculated the increased income opportunity for Black American workers”).</p>
<p><strong><em>Enrollment. </em></strong>Our research points to several potential remedies for increasing enrollment. HBCUs could draw more K–12 students into the college pipeline by partnering with school districts and allowing students to take college courses (and potentially complete an associate’s degree) while in high school. They could also hold summer camps for younger students to build interest and awareness of HBCU programs and opportunities. Additionally, HBCUs could target nontraditional student populations for enrollment. Morehouse College recently announced a discounted online program for people with some college credits.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="277ca8c1-df90-49df-9e63-530db8a26adf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="277ca8c1-df90-49df-9e63-530db8a26adf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emma Bowman and Ari Shapiro, “New Morehouse College program encourages Black men to complete unfinished degrees,” NPR,
    February 25, 2021, npr.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The program aims to serve “more than two million Black men who pursued a higher education [but] never finished their degree,” according to the US Census Bureau.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3924827f-ab73-4929-af2d-c84389dcdeef"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3924827f-ab73-4929-af2d-c84389dcdeef" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Educational attainment in the United States: 2019,” US Census Bureau, March 30, 2020, census.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p><em><strong>Retention and graduation rates.</strong></em> Beyond a focus on increasing enrollment, HBCUs could dedicate additional resources toward boosting retention
and graduation rates. Many HBCUs have large populations of low-income and first-generation college students who are less likely to stay the course and graduate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1e03a292-5fe1-4dc3-9f13-ec6213240245"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1e03a292-5fe1-4dc3-9f13-ec6213240245" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The HBCU Effect, UNCF, uncf.org; Robert Kelchen, “A look at Pell Grant recipients’ graduation rates,” Brookings Institution, October 25, 2017, 		 brookings.edu.</span></span></span></a></span> Some HBCUs are seeking to improve their support for these students and increase the odds that they will graduate. Dillard University, Howard University, and Morgan State University, for instance, have partnered with the Lumina Foundation on its HBCU Student Success Initiative, in which the institutions collaboratively develop and share best practices for retaining and graduating students, with a particular focus on supporting sophomores.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2694b056-fcf8-4163-a995-fa451614b427"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2694b056-fcf8-4163-a995-fa451614b427" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Toya Barnes-Teamer, Haley Grover, and Cristen Moore, “Collaboration beats competition: HBCUs work together for student success,” Lumina 		  Foundation, November 20, 2019, luminafoundation.org.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>HBCUs can also ensure that their degree programs are preparing students for high-paying, in-demand careers. For instance, McKinsey’s BEM and MGI research shows that relatively few Black students choose courses of study that could <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">set them on a medical path</a>. HBCUs could provide more career and academic coaching to support students’ awareness of the medical field and what’s required to obtain, say, chemistry or biology degrees. They could also establish new degrees and training programs to develop and support professionals in high-tech fields. For instance, IBM is partnering with 13 HBCUs to build a new Quantum Center that gives students access to IBM quantum computers, as well as educational support and research opportunities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="41b61014-7abd-4a3f-8295-8af7b73ac5d8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="41b61014-7abd-4a3f-8295-8af7b73ac5d8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>IBM Research Blog</em>, “HBCU center driving diversity and inclusion in quantum computing,” blog entry by Kayla Lee and Benita Zazueta, 		 September 17, 2020, ibm.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, tech giants such as Netflix are partnering with HBCUs to offer coding boot camps for students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ded17f3f-9e03-43d2-9ffd-227c3d0af64a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ded17f3f-9e03-43d2-9ffd-227c3d0af64a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Netflix Pathways Boot Camps,” Netflix, July 2021, netflix.2u.com.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>HBCUs could also play a role in reskilling and upskilling, especially as increases in automation create <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-in-black-america">additional threats to Black employment</a>. Tennessee State University, for instance, has worked for several years to teach coding and application design to students and adults in the community.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9a2b0379-41c6-4129-baee-951f82df25d6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9a2b0379-41c6-4129-baee-951f82df25d6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Empowering HBCU communities through coding and creativity,” Tennessee State University, tnstate.edu.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<h3>2. Accelerating Black business ownership and entrepreneurship</h3>
<p>There is an estimated <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">$1.6 trillion gap in aggregate revenue</a> between Black-owned and non-Black-owned businesses across the US economy—a figure that has only grown over recent decades. McKinsey research shows that there are fewer Black-owned businesses in the United States, and the ones that do exist are smaller than their peers. Black-owned businesses constitute just 2 percent of the nation’s total businesses with multiple employees, and they account for less than 1 percent of US gross revenue.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b1082b78-e3d7-4535-82ed-108ebc6d4af9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b1082b78-e3d7-4535-82ed-108ebc6d4af9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“U.S. minority-owned firms,” US Minority Business Development Agency, January 2016, mbda.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> Further, Black-owned businesses have been financially limited by both geography and industry; many are concentrated in the South and in industries like haircare, beauty, and social services, which grow less than 2 percent per year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="edd63f46-64e7-4697-8386-89c53f32a499"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="edd63f46-64e7-4697-8386-89c53f32a499" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dedrick Asante-Muhammad et al., “Black entrepreneurship’s lethal pre-existing condition: The racial wealth divide during the COVID crisis,” 		  NCRC, April 6, 2021, ncrc.org. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Lack of capital is a critical issue for Black-owned businesses. Black entrepreneurs <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">start businesses</a> with roughly a third of the capital of their White counterparts. And more than half of Black business owners state that accessing capital is a constant challenge in scaling their businesses.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b41b64ab-a1e7-4b11-b254-c226aea4a5b8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b41b64ab-a1e7-4b11-b254-c226aea4a5b8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jeffrey McKinney, “56% of black entrepreneurs say gaining access to capital is a lingering challenge, lessening their ability to grow,”
    BLACK ENTERPRISE, March 1, 2021, blackenterprise.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The lack of capital can also leave existing businesses vulnerable to financial shocks and economic downturn. During the COVID-19 pandemic, for instance, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19s-effect-on-minority-owned-small-businesses-in-the-united-states">Black-owned businesses closed</a> nearly twice as fast as all other businesses.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36603180-0b69-4a6f-85a1-154dce3ea8c4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36603180-0b69-4a6f-85a1-154dce3ea8c4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Robert Fairlie, <em>The impact of Covid-19 on small business owners: Evidence of early-stage losses from the April 2020 current population 		  survey</em>, Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research working paper, number 20-022, May 2020, siepr.stanford.edu.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>What’s more, Black businesses receive a very small percentage of start-up capital: $1 billion of the total $150 billion invested in US start-ups in 2020, or just 0.7 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a5c81f0a-bf5d-49d3-8c99-984929d6318b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a5c81f0a-bf5d-49d3-8c99-984929d6318b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Gené Teare, “Highlighting notable funding to Black founders in 2020,” Crunchbase News, February 12, 2021, news.crunchbase.com. </span></span></span></a></span> Black women received the smallest share of start-up capital (0.27 percent), and just 4 percent of the entire venture-capital workforce is Black, with 2 to 3 percent in investment decision-making positions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8822ede0-f174-4750-8b14-806f402f25b9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8822ede0-f174-4750-8b14-806f402f25b9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">VC Human Capital Survey: Venture capital diversity, equity, and inclusion, Deloitte, March 2021, deloitte.com.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>There is an opportunity, then, for HBCUs to help train and develop the next generation of Black entrepreneurs and to help Black entrepreneurs scale up and sustain businesses in their communities. This could create $5 billion to $12 billion in incremental revenue and $250 million to $1.2 billion in incremental business profits using a 5 to 10 percent estimated profit margin.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="13e57ee2-3adb-4dbe-ba90-b151f22f83d9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="13e57ee2-3adb-4dbe-ba90-b151f22f83d9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis using the average revenue of a Black-owned business as $1 million on the low end or the average revenue of a non-Black-owned business as $2.4 million at the high end. Michael Chui, Vivian Hunt, JP Julien, James Manyika, Bob Sternfels, Shelley Stewart III, 		  Jonathan Woetzel, and Haiyang Zhang, “<a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">The economic state of Black America: What is and what could be</a>,” McKinsey Global Institute,
    June 17, 2021. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>HBCUs can continue to encourage entrepreneurship through strong on-campus business programs or by introducing full-degree or certificate programs in entrepreneurship. HBCUs could also work to create partnerships with venture-capital firms to help match students with potential employers, thereby filling their pipelines with high-quality, diverse talent. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Spotlight on HBCUs and entrepreneurship</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Atlanta, Georgia</strong>—a hub of Black entrepreneurship<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3202fd84-0e34-4e6d-8bbf-39244a55b070"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3202fd84-0e34-4e6d-8bbf-39244a55b070" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cameron Albert-Deitch, “How a new generation of Black entrepreneurs built Atlanta’s hot startup scene,” Inc., Winter 2018/2019, inc.com.</span></span></span></a></span>—will soon become home to the Propel Center, an epicenter of entrepreneurship knowledge, tools, and resources for HBCU students. The 50,000-square-foot, state-of-the-art facility will be located next to Clark Atlanta University. It will feature lecture halls, innovation learning labs, and on-campus residences, as well as unique programs, including externship opportunities, access to an in-house incubator and cross-curricular arts, and agritech and social-justice programs. HBCU students attending any of the schools in the Atlanta University Center Consortium (Clark Atlanta, Spelman, Morehouse, and Morehouse School of Medicine) will have access both physically and virtually to the Propel Center—potentially spurring the entrepreneurial pursuits of thousands of students annually. </p>
<p><strong>Howard University</strong> has supported student entrepreneurship for decades through its academic programming, funding opportunities, and supplementary curricula. Howard’s Institute for Entrepreneurship, Leadership, and Innovation (ELI) provides specialized training and education, offers experiential learning opportunities, and partners with national organizations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c9ec2283-3328-4993-a99a-166f08d2a5fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c9ec2283-3328-4993-a99a-166f08d2a5fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Howard University, University Innovation Fellows, universityinnovation.org and 21st Century Advantage Program, Howard University School of Business, howard.edu. </span></span></span></a></span> And through Howard’s 21st Century Advantage Program, teams of business students develop their ideas and gain real-world experience alongside corporate partners.</p>
<p><strong>Spelman and Morehouse</strong> will soon house the newly created Center for Black Entrepreneurship (CBE) in partnership with the Black Economic Alliance and Bank of America.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9534aa08-3197-49b1-9f2d-a9bcec837297"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9534aa08-3197-49b1-9f2d-a9bcec837297" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“BEA Foundation, Spelman College, and Morehouse College to open the Center for Black Entrepreneurship,” Black Economic Alliance, February 22, 2021, blackeconomicalliance.org.</span></span></span></a></span> The CBE will have a physical presence on both campuses through which students will have access to entrepreneurship-oriented curricula and faculty. The CBE plans to connect students with potential investors and to fund promising student ventures. It also hopes to develop partnerships with start-ups and build co-curricular programming with other university programs, thereby giving students a diverse network of potential thought partners.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Additionally, HBCUs could establish campus accelerator or incubator programs that could offer students funding and investment support, and perhaps even more important, hands-on experience in building a start-up business—all in an academic setting. Some traditional venture-capital firms, including Andreessen Horowitz and SoftBank, have made multimillion dollar pledges to invest in Black entrepreneurs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="12fd40bc-6a1e-475a-a89a-1fc6052e384b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="12fd40bc-6a1e-475a-a89a-1fc6052e384b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nitasha Tiku, “Black tech founders say venture capital needs to move past ‘diversity theater,’” <em>Washington Post</em>, June 10, 2020, 			  washingtonpost.com. </span></span></span></a></span> Such companies could go even further and dedicate money directly to HBCU-housed funds, allowing HBCUs to make investment decisions that would most benefit their communities (see sidebar “Spotlight on HBCUs and entrepreneurship”).</p>
<p>By developing the next generation of Black entrepreneurs, HBCUs can have an outsize impact on equity and diversity.</p>
<h3>3. Removing barriers for Black consumers</h3>
<p>Black consumers spend <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">over $800 billion every year</a>, but research suggests that nearly $300 billion more could be unlocked if their purchasing experiences weren’t blocked by several factors, including food deserts (regions and communities with limited access to fresh food)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6b9f2151-690f-443e-90cc-f7b25bbd78a4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6b9f2151-690f-443e-90cc-f7b25bbd78a4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Around 8.3 million Black Americans, one in every five Black households, live in “food desert” areas; lack of access to fresh, affordable food can 		  contribute to poor nutrition, which can lead to larger health implications.</span></span></span></a></span> and lack of broadband access.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6f9783cf-c242-48e4-ac80-af8fd279c5f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6f9783cf-c242-48e4-ac80-af8fd279c5f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Black households are 50 percent more likely to live in areas with limited broadband service. “Form 477 Census Tract Data on Internet Access 		  Services,” US Federal Communications Commission, October 14, 2020, fcc.gov.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Many HBCUs are situated in areas where Black consumers’ needs are not being met. For instance, 82 percent of HBCUs are in broadband deserts;
50 percent are in food deserts; and 35 percent are in areas without superstores that could offer consumers a full range of groceries, furniture,
and clothing. McKinsey research suggests that if HBCUs could share resources with students and communities, an additional $1 billion in additional consumer expenditures could be unleashed (by satisfying the unmet consumer demand in these communities).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="527ac481-f332-40d2-b830-7ad0996df98e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="527ac481-f332-40d2-b830-7ad0996df98e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Analysis is based on the US Census Bureau American Community Survey 2019, US Bureau of Labor Statistics Consumer Expenditure Survey 		  2019, and McKinsey Consumer Survey 2021 (6,200 respondents). The estimates are around 70,000 households in HBCU census tracts, 		  around $40,000 spend in Black households, and around 31 percent in unmet demand.</span></span></span></a></span> (Exhibit 4)</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility/pub-hbcu-small-ex4-rj.gif"><img alt="Black Americans experience the digital divide in communities where historically Black colleges and universities are situated." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/how%20hbcus%20can%20accelerate%20black%20economic%20mobility/pub-hbcu-small-ex4-rj.gif" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>For example, HBCUs can establish campus community gardens and consider ways to provide organic produce to food-insecure students and members of the broader community. They can also offer educational programs on the importance of nutrition and fresh food. That is what the University of the District of Columbia has done with its creation of five urban food hubs in various sites across metro Washington, DC.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="785e7c34-426f-422e-9bcf-b794fffb388b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="785e7c34-426f-422e-9bcf-b794fffb388b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Urban food hubs model, University of the District of Columbia, July 2021, udc.edu.</span></span></span></a></span> The hubs use production systems that factor in the urban environment, including raised beds for gardens and green roofs and hydroponic and aquaponic growing methods. The hubs provide students and community members with access to fresh food. The initiative has created jobs, improved public health, mitigated water-management problems—and ultimately created a measure of urban resilience in the metro area. </p>
<p>HBCUs could also optimize their existing broadband infrastructures and arrange to give community members affordable access to the network. With greater access to broadband, more people could then take advantage of virtual economic and educational resources that would otherwise be unavailable to them. </p>
<p>To provide more connectivity, HBCUs may need to look for partners. Benedict College is working with the University of South Carolina (USC) to provide open access to eight computer labs across the state of South Carolina, including one on Benedict College’s campus. The labs are located in areas where local school districts, HBCUs, the South Carolina Technical College System, and community members can get to them relatively easily. Benedict College and USC will supply the space, maintenance, and utilities so the labs will be free to users. This effort was funded by a $6 million Governor’s Emergency Education Relief (GEER) fund.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a92ca86e-4a06-42ec-be39-55a172f028c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a92ca86e-4a06-42ec-be39-55a172f028c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Gov. Henry McMaster provides $6 million in GEER funds for community computer labs,” Benedict College, March 31, 2021, benedict.edu.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>4. Supporting the savings and investments of Black households</h3>
<p>The US racial wealth gap is the product of intergenerational transfers, lower incomes, and a lack of financial inclusion. BEM and MGI research shows, for instance, that the median Black household has just one-eighth the wealth of the median White household, with inheritances driving 60 percent of the disparity in annual flows. Smaller paychecks also mean that Black households save $75 billion less annually than White households.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f7f3dd0c-71e0-4420-aaab-81c050a36c65"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f7f3dd0c-71e0-4420-aaab-81c050a36c65" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF),” US Federal Reserve Board, May 20, 2021, federalreserve.gov.</span></span></span></a></span>  Black households are one-third less likely to own their homes, and the median value of those homes is one-third lower than those of White-owned homes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="05ca8970-9947-4bb3-b9c2-2c9fd253850c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="05ca8970-9947-4bb3-b9c2-2c9fd253850c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF),” US Federal Reserve Board, May 20, 2021, federalreserve.gov.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>Additionally, 14 percent of Black adults are unbanked—that is, they are not being served by a bank or similar financial institution. Of unbanked households, 29 percent cited insufficient money to meet minimum-balance requirements as the main reason for not having a bank account, while more than 16 percent said they do not trust banks.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ff991f5-4173-4687-af34-5028498413bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ff991f5-4173-4687-af34-5028498413bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2019 FDIC survey: How America banks: household use of banking and financial services, FDIC, fdic.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> Proximity was less of a factor, with just 2.2 percent of respondents citing inconvenient bank locations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9209ce2b-7a9f-4503-a7db-df4a03103423"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9209ce2b-7a9f-4503-a7db-df4a03103423" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2019 FDIC survey: How America banks: household use of banking and financial services, FDIC, fdic.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>HBCUs can help bolster students’ financial well-being while minimizing postgraduation financial obligations that can inhibit students’ savings and investing potential. Because of the racial wealth gap, a large percentage of HBCU students take out loans, often for large amounts: in 2017, HBCU students took out 32 percent more federal debt per student than non-HBCU students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6632602f-c2a0-4f3b-be51-798421b9fe74"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6632602f-c2a0-4f3b-be51-798421b9fe74" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrea Fuller and Josh Mitchell, “The student-debt crisis hits hardest at historically Black colleges,” <em>Wall Street Journal</em>, April 17, 2019, wsj.com.</span></span></span></a></span> McKinsey research shows that if the amount of federal debt awarded per year to HBCU students were equal to that awarded to students at peer institutions, HBCU students would accrue $280 million less in loan debt, which would significantly increase their ability to save and invest. To help their students achieve this parity, HBCUs could expand their scholarship offerings and secure more federal grants.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="66b911f9-e4d8-4d49-a420-39ff160939f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="66b911f9-e4d8-4d49-a420-39ff160939f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Analysis is based on US Department of Education data: total amount of federal student loans awarded to undergraduate students in the
    2018–19 school year is $1.15 billion; divided HBCU total federal debt by individual HBCU–non-HBCU ratio (1.32).</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>HBCUs also have an opportunity to address banking barriers and <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">help to remove predatory debt traps</a> for students and community members. Because HBCUs are often highly trusted institutions in their communities, they can connect their students and communities with more inclusive financial services—for example, ones without minimum-balance requirements. </p>
<p>Financial well-being, already a common topic at universities, could be an area of focus for HBCUs. They could serve as a knowledge hub for the broader community and offer public seminars on personal investing or cryptocurrencies. The Society for Financial Education and Professional Development has created a student ambassador program that trains students at 15 HBCUs in personal financial concepts so that they can teach others in turn.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9092e855-924a-4dfa-a84f-322989239b94"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9092e855-924a-4dfa-a84f-322989239b94" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Student Ambassador Program, Society for Financial Education & Professional Development, Inc., July 2021, sfepd.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Spotlight on HBCUs and financial well-being</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Fisk University</strong> has partnered with several financial institutions, including Bank of America, the Mortgage Bankers Association, and Wells Fargo, to introduce students to potential careers in mortgage and real-estate finance.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="edd964d1-d94d-4650-82bf-93aa2002fc83"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="edd964d1-d94d-4650-82bf-93aa2002fc83" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Fisk University to launch Center For Financial Advancement,” Fisk University, September 11, 2017, fisk.edu.</span></span></span></a></span> The center provides training on these topics and others, including banking and savings basics, student-loan debt, homeownership, credit reports, and overall financial capability. Fisk’s program, the Center
for Financial Advancement, launched in 2017 and since then has expanded to other HBCUs. </p>
<p><strong>Morgan State University</strong> opened its FinTech Center in 2019, which is dedicated to the study of blockchain, cryptocurrency, and the digital finance industry.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5f5768d0-a631-49c3-9df6-ea9aea01b9c6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5f5768d0-a631-49c3-9df6-ea9aea01b9c6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The FinTech Center, Morgan State University, July 2021, fintech.morgan.edu.</span></span></span></a></span> The FinTech Center partnered with Binance.US to host the Battle for the Cryptos, a cryptocurrency trading competition for HBCU students. Morgan State has convened faculty from more than 30 HBCUs to synthesize the latest research, trends, and breakthroughs in blockchain. </p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>And as the financial industry moves away from traditional brick-and-mortar banks and into mobile banking and neobanks—which operate exclusively online—HBCUs have an opportunity to connect their students and communities with innovative financial-management products that may better fit their needs (see sidebar “Spotlight on HBCUs and financial well-being”). </p>
<p>Through carefully selected partnerships and the right learning programs, HBCUs can give students and community members opportunities to increase their savings and wealth, while limiting the risks and concerns Black Americans associate with traditional banking services. </p>
<h3>5. Serving Black residents</h3>
<p>The quality of education, healthcare, and other essential services varies immensely among communities across the United States, but even more so in Black neighborhoods. </p>
<p>Consider the quality of education: K–12 education is funded through property taxes; thus, the national average for annual instructional spending in public-school districts in which 75 percent or more of the student population is Black is <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">$1,800 less per pupil</a> than in predominantly White school districts. Research shows that although spending per pupil is not the only factor determining educational outcomes, per-student sustained spending
does matter.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0cf22e2c-fa2a-4c4f-a36c-c67e19200383"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0cf22e2c-fa2a-4c4f-a36c-c67e19200383" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mark Dynarski, “It’s not nothing: The role of money in improving education,” Brookings Institution, March 2, 2017, brookings.edu. </span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>The situation is even more concerning when it comes to healthcare. Lack of access to healthcare and insurance can have serious consequences, including a racial gap in life expectancy that has widened to five years between White and Black Americans: <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">a McKinsey analysis</a> of 2021 county health rankings shows that if that gap didn’t exist, there might be 2.1 million more Black Americans alive today. Counties where HBCUs are located account for around 500,000 of those lives.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right"
